definition: to end a relationship/to break off diplomatic ties
to break/to snap/to cut off/to give up or abstain from sth/to judge/(usu. used in the negative) absolutely/definitely/decidedly
to hand over/to deliver/to pay (money)/to turn over/to make friends/to intersect (lines)/variant of 跤[jiao1]

sentences.english: Beijing severed ties with the Vatican in 1951.
sentences.chinese: 中国于1951年和梵蒂冈断交。

sentences.english: They pledged not to break relations with the country.
sentences.chinese: 他们保证不和这个国家断交。

sentences.english: The taxiway bridge have been built for long years and with high loading.
sentences.chinese: 机场滑行道桥建筑年限久，荷载大，断交难。

sentences.english: She gave Tom the ax last night.
sentences.chinese: 她昨晚突然跟汤姆断交了。

sentences.english: She's just broken up with her boyfriend.
He breaks with Peking University due to his connection with the royal family of the former Qing Dynasty.
sentences.chinese: 因与清室的关系，王国维又与北京大学断交。

sentences.english: From the "cut I broke off diplomatic relations, " in Young People understand the importance of select friends.
sentences.chinese: 从“割席断交”中明白青少年交友选择的重要性。

definition: to become enemies/to become hostile towards
to rupture/to burst open/to break/to break off relations with/a rupture
to quarrel/to fall out with sb
to have an acrimonious falling-out/to shed all pretense of cordiality/to tear into each other
to make friends again/to renew old cordial relations
to associate (with)/to have contact (with)/to hang out (with)/to date/(interpersonal) relationship/association/contact
NATO/abbr. for 北大西洋公約組織|北大西洋公约组织[Bei3 Da4 xi1 Yang2 Gong1 yue1 Zu3 zhi1], North Atlantic Treaty Organization
to go through/to pass through/to be in general use
